identity.biochemicalTests: Obligate intracellular Gram-negative pleomorphic coccobacillus. Does not grow on standard bacteriological media. Diagnosis is primarily through serology or PCR.

clinicalProfile.summary: Coxiella burnetii is the causative agent of Q fever, a worldwide zoonosis. Humans are typically infected by inhaling aerosols from infected animals, primarily cattle, sheep, and goats. The clinical presentation ranges from a self-limiting flu-like illness (acute Q fever) to a life-threatening chronic infection, most commonly endocarditis.
pathophysiologyPearls: C. burnetii exists in two antigenic phases: phase I (highly infectious, found in nature) and phase II (less infectious, found in vitro). The antibody response to these phases is key to distinguishing acute from chronic infection.
The organism replicates within host macrophages, leading to granulomatous inflammation.

clinicalSyndromes.description: An abrupt onset, self-limiting febrile illness, often with pneumonia or hepatitis. Occurs 2-3 weeks after exposure.

Occurs in <5% of patients, months to years after acute infection. The most common manifestation is culture-negative endocarditis. Other forms include vascular, bone, and chronic liver infections. It is 100% fatal if untreated.

stagesOfIllness.details: Characterized by a predominant antibody response to the phase II antigen.
Characterized by a high-titer antibody response to the phase I antigen.

highRiskPopulations: Farmers, veterinarians, abattoir workers, and others with livestock exposure.
Individuals with pre-existing valvular heart disease, aortic aneurysm, or vascular grafts (risk for chronic Q fever).
transmissionVectors: Aerosolization of infected animal birth products, milk, or excreta.
prognosisNotes: Acute Q fever is usually mild and self-resolving.
Chronic Q fever, especially endocarditis, is fatal if not treated.

generalNotes: Treatment should be initiated as soon as Q fever is suspected.

drugs.comments: To prevent premature labor. Discontinue prior to delivery.

notes: See Endocarditis, Q fever for more details.

testingIndications: Febrile illness in a person with exposure to livestock.
methodologyNotes: Serology is the cornerstone of diagnosis. PCR is useful in early infection.
Standard blood cultures will not grow C. burnetii.

specialTests.purpose: To detect IgG and IgM antibodies to phase I and phase II antigens. A fourfold rise in phase II IgG is diagnostic of acute infection. A high phase I IgG titer (>=1:1024) is diagnostic of chronic infection.
To detect C. burnetii DNA in whole blood or serum. Sensitivity decreases rapidly after antibiotic initiation.
To detect C. burnetii antigens in infected tissue.
To detect persistent focal infections, such as vascular graft infections or osteomyelitis.

diagnosticNotes.summary: Diagnosis relies on a combination of clinical suspicion, epidemiological links, and specific laboratory tests, primarily serology (IFA) and PCR.
diagnosticNotes.biosafetyWarning: Culture of Coxiella burnetii requires Biosafety Level 3 (BSL-3) facilities and is rarely performed for diagnosis.
